Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: L-MAP: Pre-service Middle School Teachers' Knowledge of Mathematical Argumentation and Proving

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of mathematics teacher education needs a strong understanding of pre-service teachers' knowledge about the practice of mathematical argumentation and proof, including the development of this knowledge, to effectively move pre-service teachers toward a more sophisticated understanding and enactment of this practice with their own students. The integrated research and educational activities will contribute to the knowledge base teacher education programs need to effectively prepare middle school teachers for meeting the challenges of how to make reasoning and proof an integral aspect of instructional practice. The research results have the potential to guide teacher educators and educational researchers concerned with strengthening pre-service teachers' ability to make reasoning and proving an integral aspect of school mathematics. Consequently, pre-service teachers will be better equipped to develop mathematical reasoning skills in their future students and to support their students in learning mathematics with understanding. Given this country's growing need for a competent STEM workforce, helping all students learn mathematics in a way that supports deeper understanding is a priority. Additionally, the support of early CAREER scholars in mathematics education will add to the capacity of the country to address issues in mathematics education in the future.
The objective of this program of research is to examine how middle school pre-service teachers' knowledge of mathematical argumentation and proving develops in teacher preparation programs. The project explores the research question: What conceptions of mathematical reasoning and proving do middle school preservice teachers hold in situations that foster reasoning about change, proportionality, and proportional relationships, as they enter their mathematics course sequence in their teacher preparation program, and how do these conceptions evolve throughout the program? This development will be studied along three dimensions: (a) pre-service teachers' own ability to formulate mathematical arguments, (b) their ability to analyze mathematical arguments, and (c) their ability to analyze situations that engage students in mathematical argumentation and proving. Cross-sectional and longitudinal studies of 60 pre-service teachers' models, or systems of interpretation, of mathematical argumentation and proof in curricular context that foster reasoning about change, proportionality and proportional relationships will be conducted to provide an understanding of the trajectory that captures how pre-service teachers develop their knowledge of mathematical argumentation and proving throughout their university mathematics preparation program and into their student teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has contributed tools for helping prospective teachers learn about mathematical argumentation—a skill integral to the development of mathematical knowledge and essential for student success in all STEM-related fields. The grant provided a research-based understanding of the knowledge of mathematical argumentation that prospective teachers who prepare to teach grades 1-8 mathematics develop in their mathematics courses throughout their teacher preparation. The project consisted of a series of teaching experiments that were conceptualized as an instructional sequence—construct-critique-refine mathematical arguments. The overarching goal was to help prospective teachers position argumentation as a tool for engaging K-8 students in the disciplinary practice of doing mathematics.

The project provided research-based insights into the design of learning environments that address three interrelated aspects of teacher knowledge for teaching mathematical argumentation: (a) prospective teachers’ learning about and their ability to formulate mathematical arguments, (b) their ability to analyze and critique mathematical arguments, and (c) their ability to analyze and identify situations that have the potential to engage K-8 students in mathematical argumentation. The project also explored three teaching competencies: (a)  prospective teachers’ ability to notice students’ mathematical arguments, (b) their ability to assess the validity of student reasoning and strategies, and (c) their ability to select student arguments for class discussions to enhance students’ argumentation skills.

First, the project has shown a sequence of learning activities that promote deductive-like reasoning. Those activities (1) provide prospective teachers with language for discussing the nature of mathematical arguments; (2) engage prospective teachers in generating arguments about complex, non-routine problem-situations with a finite problem-domain; (3) support prospective teachers’ understanding of the value of the systematic enumeration and elimination while constructing arguments within the finite problem-domain; and (4) engage prospective teachers in collective argumentation.

The project also documented differences in prospective teachers’ noticing skills of student reasoning and arguments relative to the nature of artifacts of student work that prospective teachers analyze (i.e., written artifacts or video records). The results have shown that without providing any intentional instruction that targets noticing skills, prospective teachers are more deliberate to focus on mathematically significant aspects of student reasoning when analyzing students’ written arguments than analyzing video records of students engaged in argumentation. This outcome has implications for designing learning environments for supporting prospective teachers’ noticing skills. Interventions that target the development of professional noticing skills of student mathematical thinking could capitalize on prospective teachers’ initial noticing skills and consequently begin with activities that engage prospective teachers in analyzing student written work.

Furthermore, the project contributed an understanding of prospective teachers’ interpretation of mathematical tasks that elicit student engagement in argumentation. By describing the kinds of opportunities for argumentation prospective teachers envision when posing tasks to engage students in argumentation, the project has extended the existing analytical models for engagement in mathematical argumentation and provided a framework for the design of tasks that support student engagement in argumentation.

The project results were disseminated at several national and international conferences (e.g., North American Chapter for the Psychology in Mathematics Education Annual Conference, International Congress on Mathematical Education,  National Council of Mathematics Teachers Research Conference, Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators Annual Conference) and through journal publications. In addition to making direct contributions to research on mathematical argumentation and teacher preparation, this project engaged two post-doctoral researchers and eight undergraduate/graduate students in mathematics education research providing the opportunity for their professional growth.
